{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox museum | name = Louvre Abu Dhabi | native_name = اللوفر أبوظبي | native_name_lang = ar | logo = Louvre Abu Dhabi Logo.svg | logo_upright = 175px | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Louve Abu Dhabi.jpg | image_upright = 175px | alt = | caption = East side view of the Louvre Abu Dhabi. | coordinates = {{coord|24.5336639|54.3984611|region:AE_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | established = {{Start date|2017|11|08|df=y}} | dissolved = | location = [[Saadiyat Island]], [[Abu Dhabi]] | type = [[Art Museum]] | collections = | collection_size = 35,000 <ref>{{cite web|title=France to Open New Louvre in Abu Dhabi - washingtonpost.com|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/06/AR2007030600822_pf.html|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> | visitors = | founder = | director = Manuel Rabaté <ref name="managment">{{cite web|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi Director and Deputy Director appointed|url=https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/Louvre_Abu_Dhabi_Director_and_Deputy_Director_appointed-ZAWYA20160920091442/|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> | leader_type = Deputy Director | leader = Hissa Al Dhaheri <ref name="managment"/> | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = [[Jean Nouvel]] | historian = | owner = [[Abu Dhabi Tourism & Culture Authority]] | publictransit = | website = {{URL|www.louvreabudhabi.ae/en}} }}
The '''Louvre Abu Dhabi''' is an [[art museum|art]] and [[civilization]] [[museum]], located in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]. The museum was established on 8 November 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/watch-live-emmanuel-macron-and-uae-leaders-formally-open-louvre-abu-dhabi-1.674159.|title=Emmanuel Macron and UAE leaders formally open Louvre Abu Dhabi|publisher=}}</ref> It is part of a thirty-year agreement between the city of Abu Dhabi and the [[Political system of France|French government]]. The museum is located on the [[Saadiyat Island#Saadiyat Cultural District|Saadiyat Island Cultural District]]. It is approximately {{convert|24000|m2|ft2}} in size, with {{convert|8000|m2|ft2}} of galleries <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.louvre.fr/en/louvre-abu-dhabi|title=The Louvre Abu Dhabi - Louvre Museum - Paris|date=6 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref>, making it the [[list of largest art museums|largest]] art museum in the [[Arabian peninsula]]. The final cost of the construction is expected to be about €600 million<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ad8fcc08-c3a5-11e7-b2bb-322b2cb39656|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|access-date=2017-11-12}}</ref>. In addition, US$525 million was paid by Abu Dhabi to be associated with the [[Louvre]] name, and an additional US$747 million will be paid in exchange for art loans, special exhibitions and management advice.<ref name="The Louvre’s Art: Priceless. The Louvre’s Name: Expensive.">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/07/arts/design/07louv.html | publisher = [[New York Times]] | title= Riding, Alan | date = 2007-03-07| accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref>
Artworks from around the world are showcased at the museum, with particular focus placed upon bridging the gap between [[Eastern art|Eastern]] and [[Western art]].<ref name="Vincent Van Gogh, Andy Warhol, Claude Monet and Henri Matisse in Louvre Abu Dhabi">{{cite news | url = http://www.glammonitor.com/2014/10/21/middle-eastern-art-lovers-rejoice-louvre-finally-coming-abu-dhabi/ | publisher = [[Glammonitor]] | title= Vincent Van Gogh, Andy Warhol, Claude Monet and Henri Matisse in Louvre Abu Dhabi | date = 2014-10-21| accessdate=2014-10-21}}</ref>
== History == The establishment of this museum was approved by the French Parliament on 9 October 2007. The architect for the building is [[Jean Nouvel]] and the engineers are [[BuroHappold Engineering]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/culture/20071009.WWW000000436_le_louvre_abu_dhabi_verra_bien_le_jour.html|title=Le "Louvre Abu Dhabi" verra bien le jour|publisher=''[[Le Figaro]]''|language=French|date=9 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meed.com/uae/news/2008/01/louvre_abu_dhabi_agreement_signed.html|title=Abu Dhabi and Paris sign museam<!--SIC--> deal|last=Robinson|first=Victoria|date=7 January 2008 |publisher=MEED|accessdate=2008-09-12}}</ref> Jean Nouvel also designed the [[Institut du Monde Arabe]] in [[Paris]].
The museum is part of a US$27 billion tourist and cultural development for [[Saadiyat Island]], a complex which is planned to include three other museums, including a [[Guggenheim Abu Dhabi|Guggenheim Museum]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i5X29Np917I-YpiaA_XWq8oiGDZg|title=Feu vert du parlement français au futur musée "Louvre Abou Dhabi"|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609092458/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i5X29Np917I-YpiaA_XWq8oiGDZg|archivedate=9 June 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the [[Zayed National Museum]]. According to the government-sponsored website UAE Interact: "The French Museums Agency will operate in collaboration with the Tourism Development and Investment Company (TDIC), which is behind the transformation of Saadiyat Island. It will be chaired by French financier and member of the country's [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]], [[Marc Ladreit de Lacharrière]], publisher of the periodical ''[[Revue des Deux Mondes]]''."<ref name="UAE interacts">{{cite web|url=http://www.uaeinteract.com/docs/French_cultural_agency_to_steer_work_on_Louvre_Abu_Dhabi/26498.htm|title=French cultural agency to steer work on Louvre Abu Dhabi|date=2007-08-13|publisher=UAE Interact|accessdate=2008-09-17}}</ref> Bruno Maquart, the former Executive Director of [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], will take the position of Executive Director.<ref name="UAE interacts"/> {{Quote|By choosing the Louvre, the emirate of Abu Dhabi not only sealed a partnership with the world’s most visited and well-known museum, but selected one which, from its very inception, had a vocation to reach out to the world, to the essence of mankind, through the contemplation of works of art.|[[Jacques Chirac]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.menareport.com/en/business/210487|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi to be created within the Saadiyat Island Cultural District|date=2008-09-08 |publisher= [[Mena Report]]| accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref>}}
== Design == [[File:AbuDhabiLouvre2.jpg|thumb|The metallic ceiling of the Louvre Abu Dhabi was designed to reflect light into the museum like a natural palm frond.]] === Location === Saadiyat Island's Cultural District plans to house the largest single cluster of world-class cultural assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/143289.html|title=French Culture Minister heads delegation to UAE capital to seal Louvre Abu Dhabi operating framework|date=7 January 2008|publisher=AME Info|accessdate=2008-09-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030030206/http://www.ameinfo.com/143289.html|archivedate=30 October 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In addition to the Louvre Abu Dhabi these are intended to include: [[Zayed National Museum]], to be designed by [[United Kingdom]]-based architectural company [[Foster and Partners]] under the direction of [[Norman Foster, Baron Foster of Thames Bank|Lord Norman Foster]]; the [[Guggenheim Abu Dhabi]] contemporary arts museum – expected to be the world's largest Guggenheim; a performing arts centre designed by [[Zaha Hadid]]; a maritime museum with concept design by [[Tadao Ando]] and a number of arts pavilions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://universes-in-universe.org/eng/nafas/articles/2007/saadiyat_cultural_district/projects/louvre_abu_dhabi|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi| year=2007| publisher= Nafas Art Magazine | accessdate=2008-09-26}}</ref>
=== Architecture === [[File:AbuDhabiLouvre3.jpg|thumb|Fountain of light by [[Ai Weiwei]].]] The museum is designed as a "seemingly floating dome structure"; its web-patterned dome allowing the sun to filter through. The overall effect is meant to represent "rays of sunlight passing through [[date palm]] fronds in an [[oasis]]."<ref name="Art Gallery and Museum Louvre Abu Dhabi">{{cite web | url=http://www.designbuild-network.com/projects/louvre-abu-dhabi/ | title =DesignBuild Network | year = 2008 | publisher = designbuild-network.com | accessdate=2008-09-08}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.wallpaper.com/gallery/Best_new_grooming_product/1436 | title = Louvre, Abu Dhabi | date = 2007-05-07 | publisher = Wallpaper | accessdate = 2008-09-16 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090211203351/http://www.wallpaper.com/gallery/Best_new_grooming_product/1436 | archivedate = 11 February 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> The total area of the museum will be approximately {{convert|24000|m2|ft2}}. The permanent collection will occupy {{convert|6000|m2|ft2}}, and the temporary exhibitions will take place over {{convert|2000|m2|ft2}}.<ref name="The Louvre’s Art: Priceless. The Louvre’s Name: Expensive." /><ref name="ART IN THE DESERT" />
=== Engineering === BuroHappold Engineering provided multidisciplinary engineering services across the project, including structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, energy and environmental consultancy, water engineering, facade engineering, lighting design, people movement consultancy, security services and inclusive design. Their structural engineers realised the "floating dome" from 7,850 aluminium stars of varying sizes, which tessellate over eight layers to create a perforated roof structure that allows sunlight through to the spaces below. A team of specialist geotechnical and water engineers designed a watertight basement and tidal pools within the galleries to give the illusion of a "museum in the sea" while protecting artwork, artefacts and visitors from the corrosive marine environment.
=== Construction === Construction works at Louvre Abu Dhabi officially started on 26 May 2009. [[Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], the Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and the President of France, [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] inaugurated an exhibition titled, ''Talking Art: Louvre Abu Dhabi'' at the ''Gallery One'' of the [[Emirates Palace]] hotel which includes 19 works of art bought over the last 18 months for the Louvre Abu Dhabi, as well as loans from the French national museums to mark the beginning of the construction work.
Piling works in Louvre were to be completed by August 2010, with the piling and enabling works package awarded to the German specialized company (Bauer International FZE)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baueruae.ae/en/index.html|title=Bauer International FZE|website=www.baueruae.ae}}</ref>. The total of 4536 piles consisted of RC Piles and H-Piles and was completed on 3 August 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gulfnews.com/Nation/Government/10317095.html|title=Construction of historic Louvre Abu Dhabi museum starts|date=26 May 2009|author=Eman Mohammed|publisher=[[Gulf News]]|accessdate=2009-06-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529092236/http://www.gulfnews.com/nation/Government/10317095.html|archivedate=29 May 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/27/arts/design/27louv.html|title=Abu Dhabi Gets a Sampler of World Art|last=Vogel|first=Carol|date=26 May 2009|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-06-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.gulfnews.com/articles/07/10/11/10159435.html|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi gets green light|date=10 October 2007|publisher=[[Gulf News]]|accessdate=2008-09-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913182318/http://archive.gulfnews.com/articles/07/10/11/10159435.html|archivedate=13 September 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 29 October 2011, Tourism Development & Investment Company (TDIC.), the project manager owned by the government of Abu Dhabi, announced it would delay establishing the museum. The company gave no new date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tdic.ae/en/news/media-center/news/tourism-development-investment-tdic-statement-on-saadiyat-cultural-district.html|title=Statement by T.D.I.C., October, 29, 2011|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109015134/http://www.tdic.ae/en/news/media-center/news/tourism-development-investment-tdic-statement-on-saadiyat-cultural-district.html|archivedate=9 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the UAE newspapers ''[[Gulf News]]'' and ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]'', the delay could be explained by a review of the emirate's economic strategy.<ref>[http://gulfnews.com/business/economy/showcase-projects-yield-to-more-urgent-needs-1.927270 Showcase projects yield to more urgent needs, ''[[Gulf News]]'', 10 November 2011]</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TDIC outlines new roll-out of museums|url=http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/industry-insights/property/tdic-outlines-new-roll-out-of-museums|publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111031000957/http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/industry-insights/property/tdic-outlines-new-roll-out-of-museums|archivedate=31 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In January 2012 it was confirmed that the Louvre Abu Dhabi's new opening date would be 2015.<ref name="nytimes">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/27/world/middleeast/27iht-m27-gulf-louvre.html?_r=0|title=After a Sputtering Start, the Louvre Abu Dhabi Project Gathers Pace |author=SARA HAMDAN|accessdate=10 January 2013 |date=26 September 2012 |work=nytimes |publisher=The New York Times Company}}</ref>
Construction on the main phase of the museum began in early 2013 by a consortium headed by Arabtec, Constructora San José and Oger Abu Dhabi. This stage includes waterproofing and the two basement levels, along with four concrete pillars that will support the 7,000-tonne dome.<ref name="thenational">{{Cite news |url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/art/louvre-abu-dhabi-is-a-modern-marvel-in-the-making?_r=0 |title=A modern marvel in the making |author=JAMES LANGTON |accessdate=24 May 2013 |date=11 October 2013 |work=thenational |publisher=Abu Dhabi Media |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014174902/http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/art/louvre-abu-dhabi-is-a-modern-marvel-in-the-making?_r=0 |archivedate=14 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Work on the construction of the gallery spaces and initial preparation for the dome began in the fourth quarter of 2013. On 5 December 2013, the first element of the museum's canopy was lifted into place.<ref>{{cite web|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi chalks up another towering achievement|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/tourism/louvre-abu-dhabi-chalks-up-another-towering-achievement|publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]}}</ref>
On 17 March 2014 TDIC announced the completion of the first permanent gallery structure to mark the first anniversary of the start of construction. At this time, it was claimed that a total of ten million man hours had been worked and 120,538 cubic meters of concrete used.<ref>{{cite web|title=From a patch of sand to the outline of a masterpiece|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/tourism/louvre-abu-dhabi-from-patch-of-sand-to-the-outline-of-a-masterpiece|publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]}}</ref>
On 22 September, the final super-sized element in the canopy was fitted in place, marking a significant milestone in the museum's construction phase. In October, The Tourism & Development Investment Company announced that the Louvre Abu Dhabi was more than 50 percent complete.<ref>{{cite web|title=The story of the final piece of the Louvre Abu Dhabi|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/tourism/the-story-of-the-final-piece-of-the-louvre-abu-dhabis-great-puzzle|publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]}}</ref>
===Visual identity=== The three-languages [[wayfinding]] system for the Louvre Abu Dhabi was designed by [[Philippe Apeloig]], and is implemented in both Arabic and Roman script. [[Frutiger (typeface)|Frutiger LT]] typeface has been chosen for the Roman texts for its perfect readability for signage; while Lebanese typographer Kristyan Sarkis created an Arabic bespoke typeface, the LAD Arabic, based on the classic [[Naskh (script)|Naskh]] style and his Colvert Arabic font.
The design of the pictograms was inspired by the museum’s architecture, and particularly by the abstract shapes created by the rain of light filtering through the gigantic dome's [[mashrabiya]]s. Each pictogram is a combination of several of these shapes, creating silhouettes and objects.
== Collection == [[File:Leonardo da Vinci, Salvator Mundi, c.1500, oil on walnut, 45.4 × 65.6 cm.jpg|thumb|''[[Salvator Mundi (Leonardo)|Salvator Mundi]]'', c. 1500 by [[Leonardo da Vinci]], the most expensive painting ever sold as of 2017, will be displayed in Louvre Abu Dhabi.]] Questions have been raised as to the nature of the artworks to be displayed at the museum. However, according to ''The National'': "the type and nature of the exhibits planned for the Louvre Abu Dhabi have been affected to no extent by the fact the new museum would be in a Muslim country, said Mr. Loyrette."<ref name="Abu Dhabi’s Louvre to get Middle East art" />
{{Quote|Subjects and themes have been freely discussed with our partners in Abu Dhabi and no request to avoid such subjects has been made. The exhibition policy will be set up regarding excellence and high-standard quality. As a new museum we hope the Louvre Abu Dhabi will be part of the international community.|Henri Loyrette<ref name="Abu Dhabi’s Louvre to get Middle East art">{{cite news | url = http://www.thenational.ae/article/20080819/NATIONAL/393258869/1010&profile=1010 | title = Abu Dhabi’s Louvre to get Middle East art | last = Bardsley | first = Daniel | date = 2008-08-19 | publisher = The National | accessdate = 2008-09-08 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090211164644/http://www.thenational.ae/article/20080819/NATIONAL/393258869/1010%26profile%3D1010 | archivedate = 11 February 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>}}
Nevertheless, a walk through the museum reveals the absence of ancient Greek male nudes, other than medieval or Victorian era fig leaves.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://geographic.org/streetview/special_places/view_louvre_abu_dhabi_inside.php |title=Google Street View image inside Louvre Abu Dhabi |work=Geographic.org/streetview |accessdate=2018-03-19}}</ref>
It has been noted that the museum will showcase work from multiple French museums, including the [[Louvre]], the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], the [[Musée d'Orsay]] and [[Palace of Versailles]]. However, [[Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres]], the French Culture Minister, stated at the announcement that the Paris Louvre "would not sell any of its 35,000-piece collection currently on display". {{Quote|It will not be dedicated to occidental art but will show all kinds of artistic creations. It will set up a dialogue between west and east, between north and south. As such, art from the [[Middle East]] will be shown within the Louvre Abu Dhabi.|Henri Loyrette<ref name="Abu Dhabi’s Louvre to get Middle East art" />}}
In 2012, the Louvre Abu Dhabi started collecting photography, making its first acquisitions in the field, including works by [[Joseph-Philibert Girault de Prangey]], [[Roger Fenton]] and [[George Wilson Bridges]]. The museum also acquired a sculpture of a Bactrian princess dating from the third millennium BC, a pavement and fountain set from the early Ottoman period, as well as the paintings ''Breton Boys Wrestling'' (1888) by [[Paul Gauguin]] and ''The Subjugated Reader'' (1928) by [[René Magritte]].<ref>Gareth Harris (14 September 2012), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Louvre-Abu-Dhabi-acquires-its-first-photographic-works/27189 Louvre Abu Dhabi acquires its first photographic works] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921115105/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Louvre-Abu-Dhabi-acquires-its-first-photographic-works/27189 |date=21 September 2012 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref>
Further details of the museum's collection on opening were revealed in October 2014, with a number of important works to be loaned under the agreement with Agence France-Muséums and the Musée du Louvre, including [[Leonardo Da Vinci]]'s ''[[La Belle Ferronniere]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/art/louvre-abu-dhabi-to-be-first-museum-in-middle-east-to-show-a-leonardo-da-vinci-painting|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi to be first museum in the Middle East to show a Leonardo Da Vinci painting|author=Nick Leech|work=thenational.ae|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> and works by [[Henri Matisse]], a self-portrait by [[Vincent Van Gogh]], [[Jacques-Louis David]]'s ''[[Napoleon Crossing the Alps]]'' and [[Claude Monet]]'s ''Gare Saint-Lazare''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/art/van-gogh-manet-monet-and-matisse-among-artworks-to-be-lent-to-louvre-abu-dhabi#full|title=Van Gogh, Manet, Monet and Matisse among artworks to be lent to Louvre Abu Dhabi|author=Anna Seaman|work=thenational.ae|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref>
== Exhibitions == [[File:Vives reflexions Groupe F Louvre.jpg|thumb|Vives Réflexions exhibition]] The Louvre Abu Dhabi first started sharing its collection with the public through an exhibition entitled "Talking Art: Louvre Abu Dhabi," which opened in May 2009. The exhibition presented the first 19 acquisitions for the institution, including a [[Mamluk]] holy Koran from the 14th century, a 5th-century Fibula from [[Domagnano Treasure|Domagnano]], a Virgin and Child by [[Giovanni Bellini|Bellini]], and [[Piet Mondrian|Mondrian]]’s ''Composition with blue, red, yellow and black'' from 1922.<ref name="nytimes.com">Sara Amdan (26 September 2012), [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/27/world/middleeast/27iht-m27-gulf-louvre.html After a Sputtering Start, the Louvre Abu Dhabi Project Gathers Pace] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
A second exhibition, "Birth of a Museum", opened at the exhibition space Manarat Al Saadiyat in May 2013, ending in August that year. The first large-scale preview of the collection, it featured 130 works acquired by the government of Abu Dhabi for the permanent collection. They included a never-before-seen work by [[Picasso]], a Bronze Age terracotta statue from Cyprus, along with artifacts from Greece, Turkey, Japan and Syria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/sneak-peek-at-treasures-of-louvre-abu-dhabi|title=Sneak peek at treasures of Louvre Abu Dhabi|author=Emily Cleland|work=thenational.ae|accessdate=9 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160122010639/http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/sneak-peek-at-treasures-of-louvre-abu-dhabi|archivedate=22 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In May 2014, the Birth of a Museum exhibition, featuring works shown in Abu Dhabi and a number of new acquisitions opened at the Louvre in Paris. A number of new works were presented, including ''Chirisei Kyubiki'' by the Japanese artist [[Kazuo Shiraga]] and painted in 1960.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/art/abu-dhabis-birth-of-a-museum-exhibition-opens-at-louvre-in-paris#ixzz323JULj8J|title=Abu Dhabi’s Birth of a Museum exhibition opens at Louvre in Paris|author=Nick Leech|work=thenational.ae|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref>
@LouvreAbuDhabi tweeted<ref>{{cite web|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi is looking forward to displaying the Salvator Mundi by Leonardo Da Vinci|url=https://twitter.com/LouvreAbuDhabi/status/939131731864702976|website=@LouvreAbuDhabi|language=en|date=8 December 2017}}</ref> 8 December 2017 that the Louvre Abu Dhabi is looking forward to displaying the ''[[Salvator Mundi (Leonardo)|Salvator Mundi]]'' by [[Leonardo Da Vinci]]. The work was acquired, at a record price for a painting, by the [[Abu Dhabi Department of Culture & Tourism|Department of Culture & Tourism]] of Abu Dhabi for the museum.
== Other programmes == The Louvre Abu Dhabi has also been working with the [[Paris Sorbonne University Abu Dhabi]] to set up a master’s program for museum professionals to train them and help them respond to local needs.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
== Management ==
=== Contract === Louvre Abu Dhabi is an entirely separate museum from the Louvre in Paris, although the two are linked by a thirty-year branding and training agreement and the Paris Louvre is one of the 12 shareholders in Agence France-Muséums.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The thirty-year agreement, signed by [[France|French]] Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres and Sheik Sultan bin Tahnoon Al Nahyan, will prompt the construction of a Louvre museum on [[Saadiyat Island]], near central Abu Dhabi, in exchange for US$1.3 billion.<ref name="ART IN THE DESERT">{{cite web | url = http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,470356,00.html | title = Art in the Desert | publisher = [[Spiegel Online]] |date = 2007-07-03 | accessdate=2008-09-08}}</ref> The contract prohibits the creation of any similar operation with the name of the Louvre in any of the other emirates of the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar, Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Iran, or Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://de51gn.com/2008/07/30/louvre-abu-dhabis-exclusive-details/ |title=Louvre Abu Dhabi’s exclusive deal |date=30 July 2008 |publisher=de51gn.com |accessdate=2008-09-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106151120/http://de51gn.com/2008/07/30/louvre-abu-dhabis-exclusive-details/ |archivedate=6 January 2009 }}</ref> French President [[Jacques Chirac]] praised the museum deal with Abu Dhabi, saying it reflects "a certain idea of the world" in which each party to the accord, "proud of its roots and of its identity, is conscious of the equal dignity of all cultures."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/culture/20070307.FIG000000146_le_louvre_abu_dhabi_sous_une_coupole_aerienne.html|title=Le Louvre Abu Dhabi sous une coupole aérienne|last=Heliot|first=Armelle |date=2007-10-15|publisher=''[[Le Figaro]]''|language=French|accessdate=2008-09-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/sfgate/detail?blogid=15archive/&entry_id=14365|title=A Louvre for Abu Dhabi? It's a done deal|last=Gomez|first=Edward|year=2008|publisher=SFGate.com|accessdate=2008-09-16}}</ref>
=== Cost === US$525 million was paid by Abu Dhabi to be associated with the Louvre name, and an additional $747 million in exchange for art loans, special exhibitions and management advice.<ref name="The Louvre’s Art: Priceless. The Louvre’s Name: Expensive."/> Arabtec is leading a consortium that is building the museum under a $653 million contract awarded early in 2013.
=== Cost estimates === US$525 million was paid by the city of Abu Dhabi for the use of the Louvre brand name, with US$195 million payable within a month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dilanchian.com.au/ip/louvre-abu-dhabi-museum-licensing-shifts-more-than-revenues.html|title=Louvre Abu Dhabi|last=Dilanchian|first=Noric|date=13 March 2007|publisher=Dilanchian Lawyers and Consultants|accessdate=2008-09-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080729211803/http://www.dilanchian.com.au/ip/louvre-abu-dhabi-museum-licensing-shifts-more-than-revenues.html |archivedate = 2008-07-29}}</ref> In addition to this, US$247 million will be paid for the loan of artworks from the Louvre over a ten-year period, with a total of between two hundred and three hundred artworks expected. The Parisian Louvre will also be providing management advice to its [[Middle East]]ern counterpart, at a cost of US$214.5 million. An additional US$253.5 million will be paid for various special art exhibitions. A total of four exhibitions will be hosted per year over a period of fifteen years.<ref name="The Louvre’s Art: Priceless. The Louvre’s Name: Expensive."/> The city of Abu Dhabi will also make a direct donation of US$32.5 million to the Louvre to refurbish a wing of the [[Pavillon de Flore]] for the display of international art.
== Controversies ==
=== Opposition === The deal has sparked controversy in both artistic and academic circles. According to Maymanah Farhat, "the controversy that has surfaced in France is led by art historian Didier Rykner, one of the most outspoken critics of the French–Emirati deal."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zmag.org/znet/viewArticle/1730|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202080755/http://www.zmag.org/znet/viewArticle/1730|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 December 2008|title=The Louvre Abu Dhabi, Exploitation and the Politics of the Museum Industry|last=Farhat|first=Maymanah|date=27 March 2007|publisher=ZNet|accessdate=2008-09-08}}</ref> An online petition against the deal, signed by 4,650 curators, archaeologists and art historians, has insisted that French museums are not for sale.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6421205.stm|title=Gulf Louvre deal riles French art world |last=Astier|first=Henri|date=2007-03-07|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2008-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2007/03/06/louvre_museum_to_build_a_branch_in_uae/|title=France's Louvre branching to Abu Dhabi|last=Krane|first=Jim|date=2007-03-06|publisher=Boston.com |accessdate=2008-09-17}}</ref> The Louvre has been accused of behaving "like a corporation with a clearly-defined strategy: profit maximization."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.usyd.edu.au/bizart/2007/07/the_desert_louvre_a_change_in.html|title=The ‘Desert Louvre’ – a change in museum policy?|last = Koek| first=Marjolein |date=2007-07-06| publisher=[[University of Sydney]]|accessdate = 2008-09-16}}</ref>
==== Response ==== According to the ''[[New York Times]]'', "[[Henri Loyrette]], the president and director of the Louvre, has responded to growing criticism of the museum’s new policy of establishing footholds abroad, arguing that the Louvre cannot ignore the 'internationalization' of museums."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/09/arts/09arts.html?_r=1&ref=arts&oref=slogin|title=Arts, Briefly|last=Van Gelder|first=Lawrence|date=9 January 2007|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=2008-09-08}}</ref> He had the following to say in the museum's defence: {{Quote|It's a fair fee for the concession of the name. This tutelary role deserves a reward. It's normal.|Henri Loyrette}} {{Quote|We're not selling the French legacy and heritage. We want this culture to radiate to parts of the world that value it. We're proud that Abu Dhabi wants to bring the Louvre here. We're not here to transform culture into a consumer product.|Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17482641/|title=Louvre to build branch in Abu Dhabi|date=6 March 2007|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=2008-09-16}}</ref>}} [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], UAE President and Ruler of Abu Dhabi said: {{Quote|This is a major achievement in Abu Dhabi's vision to become a world-class destination bridging global cultures. This accord further strengthens international dialogue, which will embrace all cultures. This initiative is a unique milestone in international cooperation and bilateral relations and a tribute to the longstanding and friendly ties our two nations have enjoyed. It also creates an enriching environment to be treasured by and to educate generations to come. Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan.<ref name="Art Gallery and Museum Louvre Abu Dhabi" />}}
===Concerns about human rights abuse === In April 2011, [[Al Jazeera]] reported that over 120 international artists urged a boycott of both the Louvre and Guggenheim museums over concerns regarding the abuse and exploitation of construction workers employed to develop the complex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/04/20114342518230176.html|title=Artists urge Guggenheim boycott|date=3 April 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> One of the architects, Jean Nouvel, defended the treatment of the construction workers, starting that the condition of construction workers were better than some European countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/24/architect-defends-treatment-workers-louvre-abu-dhabi-jean-nouvel|title=Architect defends treatment of workers at Louvre Abu Dhabi|date=24 September 2017|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref>
